text: Welcome to Xochimilco in Mexico City, I love this part of town, partly because you can go on these really colorful boats called trajineras.
Generally, that's why people come down here to enjoy mariachis and drink micheladas on these boats
But there's another thing here, one of my favorite things in the entire place,
It is called templo de Diana, and it's a pulquería. -It's a hidden jewel.

Pulque, one of my favorite drinks here. Let's go

Pulque has a really interesting history
It was the drink of choice for the Aztecs and people here in Mexico drank it for thousands and thousands of years until
around the 1950s where the beer company started to come to Mexico. They saw this drink pulque in the same niche
they wanted to sell it, it's like a
5% alcohol drink you have with one of the boys after work, so the beer companies went out to destroy
pulque, remove the drink from the market
and they did that, they started a disinformation campaign saying that the same barrels that they ferment Pulque were used for human
feces; it destroyed pulque in
mainstream society and the beer companies
blasted up to the top. This is amazing so these barrels come every single day from the Mexican state of Hidalgo
which is a couple hours away from Mexico City.
The shelf life of pulque is very short they need one of these a day
and it spoils after one day, so this one is fresh, we're here tonight; It's gonna be the one they drink here tomorrow morning
-Aquí abajo, no se si alcanzas a ver el movimiento porque el pulque tiene vida, él solito esta moviéndose.

We have a barrel of natural pulque a barrel of pulque with sugar, and the flavored pulque is called "curados"
So they have Nuez, this is the one they make ostión with,
they have the celery one here.
And he said, to me really interesting, about the natural pulque, there's no sugar no flavor. He says it has life
because we looked in the barrel. You can actually see the pulque is slowly turning and moving
It's a fermented drink and so as it ferments it moves around inside of these fermentation barrels, so the pulque tiene vida,
the pulque is life,
that is what he said.
Now you can still see pulquerias like this, serving pulque to usually an older demographic
but there's a small resurgence of younger folk drinking pulque in Mexico. We love it,
